editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: The la≈øt words of the King of Sweden, on his Deathbed, in his royal palace at Gottenburg, before the Lords of his privy Council, on Friday the 10. of February. There being pre≈øent, Mon≈øier Trelon, Amba≈ø≈øadour of France, Sir George Ay≈øcough, a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ many other honorable per≈øonages.
div.p: THe Spirits of his Maje≈øty of Sweden, which, like a how continually bended, found no relaxation, did in the mid≈øt of the month of January, bring a feaver on his body, which fir≈øt confined him to his Chamber, and afterwards to his bed; his late lo≈ø≈øes, but e≈øpecially that at Fuenen, kept his mind in a perpetual agitation, and his courage to overcome all difficulties, did ≈øo prevaile upon him, that it brought with it the violence of a di≈øea≈øe, by denying him the benefit of ≈øleep; his di≈øea≈øe which was but a tame Ague at the fir≈øt, did by degrees become ≈øo predominant, that his Doctors of Phy≈øick, (the mo≈øt learned on that ≈øide of Europe) began to di≈øpaire of his recovery.

It plea≈øed God that at that time he had called together at Gottenburg, a council of the mo≈øt apparent of all his Nobility of Sweadland. Provi≈ø≈øion was there made for carrying on the War with more vigour, again≈øt the Emperour, the King of Denmark, and the Marquis of Brandenburgh, there potent Enemies, who had attaqued him in Pru≈ø≈øia, Pomerania, and in the Frontiers of Swedland, and given him a memorial overthrow in the I≈øland of Fuenen. Queen Mary of England, who≈øe raign was as ≈øhort, as this King of Swedlands, was oftentime heard to ≈øpeak in the fits of her deepe≈øt Melancholly, that when ≈øhe was di≈ø≈øected being dead, they ≈øhould find Calis ingraven in her heart, I forbear to make any addre≈øs of Application, but certain it is, that at this Council the Lords of Swedland, following the di≈øpo≈øition, and con≈øtitution of their King did re≈øolve, th ‚Ä¢ t every third man in the Kingdom of Sweden, ≈øhould put on Armes for the defence and propagation of their Countries Liberties It was re≈øolved that ≈øeveral Regements both of hor≈øe and foot, ≈øhould be formed out of Lapland, Gothland, and Vandals, which on the beginning of the Spring, ≈øhould like a Tempe≈øt come Thundering in, into the
de≈øolate Dominions of Powerland, and Pru≈ø≈øia, and having reduced tho≈øe places, ≈øhould carry the war into the heart of the Empire.

This was agreeable unto all, and there was no other di≈øcour≈øe heard of from Gottenburg, until you come to Stockhalme. In the mean time it plea≈øed God, that the health of the King was every day weaker then other, although he wanted for no encouragements. His Commanders were every day to att ‚Ä¢ nd him with their Re≈øolutions; his Phy≈øitians with their Cordials, and his Divines with their coun≈øels, but ≈øleep being a ≈øtranger to his body, his body began to be a ≈øtranger, and to abandon the acquaintance of his ≈øoul. It is a wonderful thing to con≈øider in how clo≈øe a twi≈øt of re≈øpondency that ≈øleep and health are united, although that one of them is the Emblem of death, and the other of Immortality.

On Friday Feburary the tenth, his Maje≈øty of Sweden, by the ≈øtrength of his weakne≈øs perceiving the weakne≈øs of his ≈øtrength, and finding nothing perfect in him≈øelf, but his Vprightne≈øs and his Memory, he commanded that his Councilors, and Lords of Sweden, ≈øhould be called before him, who accordingly having made their appearance, he did rai≈øe him≈øelf a little from his bed, and with a countenance more chearful then ordinary, he expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf unto them in the≈øe words, My Lords, my faithful Councelours, and Deer Allyes.

Many years are not yet pa≈ø≈øed, ≈øince by the guift of my renowned kin≈øwoman Queen Chri≈øtina, the crown of Sweadland, hath been devolved on me, it hath been my indeavour to follow the example of my famous Pre ‚Ä¢ ece≈ø≈øours, which was to enlarge as much as to defend their Dominions; With what ≈øucce≈ø≈øe I made war fir≈øt in Bremen, and afterwards in Poland, I believe there is no part in the world is ignorant. By the combinations, and ≈øecret practi≈øes of ≈øome Enemies neerer home, I was called from thence into Denmark, where havin both the King him≈øelf and his Kingdome at my mercy, I granted him peace, and contented with the glory of the Conque≈øt, I remitted to him the fruition of his Kingdoms. But he to require ≈øo great a f ‚Ä¢ vour entred pre≈øently into a league with the Hollander, and the Emperour to the apparent prejudice of the Crown of Sweden,; This cau≈øed me pre≈øently to return with my forces to Denmark, being much incouraged in it by the late Protector of England, had I not been
interrupted in my proceedings, by the Fleet of Holland, I had undoubtedly put a good period to that war, and made both the Emperor and the King of Denm ‚Ä¢ rk, to feel the effects of my power; I ≈øhall here make no mention of my Co≈øin, the Marquis of Brandenburg, of whom I expected better things, neither too heavily will I ≈øay the misfortune in Pomerania, to the neglect of my Brother Prince Adolphus, yet I mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that I am confident the affaires there had been carried more to my honor, and advantage, if he had executed the in≈øtructions which I gave him.

That which leaveth the greate≈øt impre≈ø≈øion of grief upon my ≈øoul, is the lo≈øs ≈øu≈øtained at Fuenen, and the impri≈øonment of many of my eminent Commanders now at Gluck ‚Ä¢ tadt, but I hope (my Lord Amba≈ø≈øadour) that the monies promi≈øed from your Ma≈øter the King of France, will be either a ≈øpeedy ran≈øome for them, or an a≈ø≈øi≈øtance unto you to force open the gates of Gluckstadt, for their deliverance.

My de≈øire is, that my mo≈øt deer Lady the Queen, may be Regent after me, during the minority of my Son, to whom I do be≈øeech God to be a father. I leave unto you the management of all affaires, both ≈øpiritual and civil, conjuring you to be zealous unto God, dutiful to your Queen, and faithful to one another.

I mu≈øt commend unto your greate≈øt care, the peace with the King of Denmark, of which already ≈øome overtures have been made, but I would have it to be ≈øuch a peace as may be mo≈øt advantagious to you, without the lea≈øt blemmi≈øh or tincture of di≈øhonour. And becau≈øe we have already found him ≈øo uncertain, I would advi≈øe you to keep El≈øenour, and Cronenburg, as Caution Towns for the performance of his promi≈øes.

As for the late renowned Queen of Sweden now at Rome, I have ≈øomething to ≈øpeak in relation to her, and her Dowry in great danger, by the ruine of Pomerania, but ‚Äî Here his ≈øpirits fainting away, he ≈øunk down on his bed, but he was immediately recovered by ≈øome excellent hot waters, that were admini≈øtred to him, while his Lords and Councilours that ≈øtood round about him, did drink hot watess as well as him≈øelf, but it was from the abundance of the teares that did flow from their eyes.

The King after a little pau≈øe, having again rai≈øed him≈øelf, with a ≈øerious eye did look upon them all, and ob≈øerving rain within door, and none without, he ≈øeemed to be much di≈øcontented at it, and thus again proceeded in his di≈øcour≈øe.

I have hitherto ≈øpoken to you as a King, I ≈øhall now ≈øpeak to you as a Chri≈øtian; Death is only terrible to the wicked, and it is not ≈øo much the fear of Death, as the ≈øence of hell that is ≈øo terrible to them, the apprehen≈øion of the torment of the one ≈øwallows up the terror of the other. Did ever any man on the rack afflict him≈øelf, becau≈øe his Mi≈øtre≈øs ≈ølighted him? did ever man that attained unto va≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and was condemned to dye for blood≈øhed and Extortion, call for the particulars of his purcha≈øe upon the Gallows? The apprehen≈øion and horror of being damned (I do not ≈øay) will cure all other ≈øadne≈øs, but certainly it will ≈øwallow it up, But I who by the mirits of my Redeemer, who by the grace of the Lord Je≈øus, do believe I ≈øhall be ≈øaved, I do de≈øire you to con≈øider with me, how great is my joy? how infinite my advantage is by this Exchange? How un≈øpeakable is the glory, and how excellent is the recompence for all the hard Marches, and the ≈øufferings in this world?

My Lords! Take the coun≈øel with you of your dying Prince, let us prepare our ≈øelves again≈øt changes, always expecting them, that ≈øo we be not ≈øurpri≈øed when they come; Oh death how bitter art thou to a man who hath promi≈øed to him≈øelf ea≈øe and fulne≈øs, by his large po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and to enjoy it for many years! it was a ≈øad Arre≈øt, that his ≈øoul was ≈øurpri≈øed the fir≈øt night.

Con≈øider with me, that afflictions are often the occa≈øion of great ≈øpiritual advantages; We mu≈øt not look upon them, as they ≈øit heavy upon us, but as they ≈øerve unto Gods ends, and the purpo≈øe of his eternal providence; When a Prince fights ju≈øtly, but un≈øucce≈ø≈øully; Could he but ≈øee the rea≈øon for which God did ≈øo order it, he would find it unrea≈øonable, nay ill, to have it otherwi≈øe. If a man could have opened but one of the pages of the Divine coun≈øail, and ob≈øerved the event of Jo≈øephs being ≈øold to the Merchants of Amaleck, he might with much rea≈øon have dryed up the young mans tears; God e≈øteemeth it one of his glories, to bring good out of evil; And therefore it is but rea≈øon that we ≈øhould leave unto God the Government of his own world, as he him≈øelf plea≈øeth, and that we ≈øhould patiently wait till the change commeth, and not envy the happine≈øs, and pro≈øperity of our enemies, fret not thy ≈øelf (≈øaith that kingly Prophet) becau≈øe of him who pro≈øpereth in his ways, becau≈øe of him who bringeth wicked devices to pa≈øs for evil doers at the la≈øt, ≈øhall be rooted out, but tho≈øe that weight upon the Lord ≈øhal ≈øtand like Mount Sion, that cannot be ≈øhaken

The La≈øt great trial is Death, for which ≈øhould we grieve, it would be of all greifes the mo≈øt unrea≈øonable; For why ≈øhould we grieve at that which is ≈øo ab≈øolutely unavoydable? It is not ≈øo much to be cared for how long we live, as how well we live, for that life is not be≈øt which is the longe≈øt, but that which is mo≈øt vertuous, and honourable: The ≈øhortning of our dayes, is an evil, wholy depending upon opinion, let us ≈øtill be ready for death, and it cannot come too ≈øoon, for let us dye young or old, we have ≈øtill an immortal ≈øoul, and do lay down our bodyes onely for a time, as that which was the in≈øtrument of our cares and troubles, and the ≈øcene of ≈øickne≈øs, and di≈øea≈øe; Let us not then (my Lords) fear that which riddeth us of all the≈øe infirmities, for by fearing it, we ≈øhall never the ≈øooner avoid it, but make it more mi≈øerable. To dye is natural and nece≈ø≈øary, but to dye poorly and ba≈øely, is that alone which can make a man mi≈øerable. No man can be a ≈ølave, but he who feareth pain, or who feareth to dye, to ≈øuch a man nothing but peaceable times can denote his inclinations, or his duty, he dependeth onely on external things for his felicity, and therefore is no longer well, then during the plea≈øure of his Enemy, a Theife or a Tyrant.

But ble≈ø≈øed is he who willingly re≈øigneth his ≈øoul into the hand of God which gave it, as into the hands of a ble≈ø≈øed Creator, and Redeemer: O ble≈ø≈øed Je≈øus thou did≈øt dye for me; grant that with joy I may ≈øubmit to thy Summons, for thou art as well my Advocate as my Judge, and came≈øt into the world to ≈øave ≈øinners; I acknowledg O Lord I am a great ≈øinner, but thy mercies are infinite. O God of mercy, and Father of all comfort, look upon the ≈øadne≈øs, and the ≈øorrowes of thy ≈øervant; my ≈øins lye heavy upon me, and pre≈øs me ≈øore, by rea≈øon of thy hot di≈øplea≈øure. My affflictions ≈øeem to be without comfort, becau≈øe they are the puni≈øhments of my ≈øins; My ≈øins have cau≈øed my ≈øorrow, yet my ≈øorrow doth not cure my ≈øins; and unle≈øs thou, O Lord, for thy own ≈øake, and meerly becau≈øe thou art good, art plea≈øed to pitty me, I ≈øhall be left forlorn, and as much without remedy as without comfort, Lord therefore pitty me; I deny my ≈øelf, and wholy depend on thee, and on the blood and merits of my redeemer: Let thy grace refre≈øh my ≈øpirit, thy comforts ≈øupport me, and thy mercies pardon me, for thou art g ‚Ä¢ od and gracious, and I throw my ≈øelf upon thy mercies. Suffer me not to let go my hold, and do thou with me, as ≈øeemeth good in thine own eyes. Thou art in finitely
more merciful then I can be mi≈øerable; O Lord make me the object of thy mercies as well in my death, as in my life; And if even in this hour ≈øhall be plea≈øed to remove me from this vale of mi≈øery, when my poor ≈øoul ≈øhall go out of the pri≈øon of this body, may it be received by Angels, and pre≈øerved from the horror and ≈øurprizal of evil ≈øpirits, and be laid up in the bo≈øome of our Lord, until the day of thy ≈øecond comming, when it ≈øhall be reunited to the body, which is now to be laid in the du≈øt, yet I doubt not but ≈øhall be rai≈øed up in joy, to live for ever, and behold the face of God, in the glories of our Lord Je≈øus, who is my Hope, my re≈øurrection, and life, my ble≈ø≈øed, and ever glorious Redeemer, to whom with the father, and the holy Spirit, be rendred all honour, and glory, now and for evermore.

Having ≈øpoke the≈øe words, his Lords and privy Coun≈øelours (who ≈øtood round about his bed) were tran≈øported with as much admiration, as they were before with grief, and taking at that time, their leave of him, they left him with two of his Chaplains, who never cea≈øed to confirme him in his holy and heavenly confidence, and to admini≈øter tho≈øe ≈øpiritual Con≈øolations to him which were ≈øuitable to the Ma≈øter of ≈øo great a war-fare, who having conquered him≈øelf as well as his Enemies, ≈øtooped his anointed head, as low as death, and in the flouri≈øh of his years, wi≈øely exchanged a ≈øea of troubles in this world, for the heaven of eternal re≈øt, and a temporal Crown for a crown of Immortality.
